</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage26"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
	UDS Division
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The UDS division is engaged in the development,
	marketing, manufacturing and servicing of medical devices for the minimally invasive diagnosis or treatment of urological disorders,
	mainly urinary stones, and other clinical indications. The UDS division
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	contributed &euro;23.8
	million
</FONT>
	to our consolidated net sales during the fiscal year ended December 31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Our UDS business is quite cyclical and generally
	linked to lengthy hospital decision and investment processes and their activities. Hence our quarterly revenues are often impacted
	and fluctuate according to these parameters, generally resulting in a higher selling activity in the last quarter of the year.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Business Overview
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The UDS division&rsquo;s primary business
	is producing and marketing devices, known as lithotripters, for the treatment of urinary tract stones by means of ESWL technology.
	ESWL uses extracorporeal shockwaves, which can be focused at urinary stones within the human body to fragment the stones, thereby
	permitting their natural elimination and preventing the need for incisions, transfusions, general anesthesia, and the resulting
	complications. The UDS division currently manufactures two models of lithotripters: the Sonolith i-move and the Sonolith i-sys.
	As of December 31, 2015, the UDS division
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	has sold
</FONT>
	827 ESWL lithotripters worldwide
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	to
	this date and
</FONT>
	actively
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	maintained or otherwise serviced 660 installed lithotripters
</FONT>
	.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	In addition to its manufacturing and selling
	of lithotripters, the UDS division also generates revenues from the leasing of lithotripters, as well as from the sale of disposables,
	spare parts and maintenance services.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Business Strategy
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The business strategy for the UDS division
	is to capitalize on its expertise in ESWL and its position in urology to achieve long-term growth as a leader in the development,
	production, marketing and distribution of minimally invasive medical devices for urological and other clinical indications. The
	UDS division manufactures its own products as part of EDAP TMS France SAS (&ldquo;EDAP TMS France&rdquo;), our wholly owned subsidiary.
	The key elements of the UDS division&rsquo;s strategy are:
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 17.85PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 17.85PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: SYMBOL">
	&middot;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Capitalize on the Current ESWL Installed Base
</I>
	. The UDS division&rsquo;s long-term growth
	strategy relies on its ability to capitalize on its extensive installed base of ESWL lithotripters to recognize ongoing revenue
	from sales of disposables, accessories, services and replacement machines. We believe that a combination of continued investment
	in lowering end-user costs and offering innovative units that are easily adaptable to various treatment environments, as well as
	a commitment to quality and service will allow the UDS division to achieve this goal. See &lsquo;&lsquo;Information on the Company&mdash;UDS
	Division Products&rsquo;&rsquo;.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 17.85PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 17.85PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: SYMBOL">
	&middot;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Capitalize on an Established Distribution Platform in Urology by Expanding Distribution Possibilities
</I>
	.
	We believe that we can achieve additional long-term growth by offering our established distribution platform in urology to other
	developers of medical technologies and acting as a distributor for their devices. Our distribution platform in urology consists
	of a series of well-established subsidiaries in Europe and Asia as well as a network of third-party distributors worldwide.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 17.85PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 17.85PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: SYMBOL">
	&middot;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Provide Manufacturing Solutions to Other Developers of Medical Technologies
</I>
	. Building upon
	its established position in the high-tech medical devices market, we believe that the UDS division can become a provider of manufacturing
	alternatives to other developers of medical technologies that do not have or do not wish to invest in their own manufacturing facilities.
	We believe that our FDA-inspected, ISO 9001 (V:2008) certified and ISO 13485 (V:2003) certified facilities allow us to offer manufacturing
	services to a wide range of potential medical equipment developers.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 35.7PT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Products
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The UDS division offers the Sonolith i-move
	(replacing Sonolith Praktis) to small and mid-size hospitals, while the Sonolith i-sys is offered to large hospitals that can afford
	a fully dedicated and integrated lithotripter. The UDS division also sells disposable parts for lithotripters, including the piezoelectric
	elements of the LT02, a machine we discontinued manufacturing in 2002) and the electrodes of the Sonolith line, which need to be
	replaced approximately every ten treatments, respectively. These parts incorporate key proprietary technologies, and the UDS division
	has retained sole marketing rights for these parts.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 0PT SOLID">
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 4IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 113.4PT">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
	The Sonolith i-move and the Sonolith i-sys
	rely on the electroconductive technology for shockwave generation. The electroconductive technology, which is derived from the
	electrohydraulic technology on which the first ESWL lithotripters were based, permits improved focusing of the shockwave, reduces
	the variability in the shockwave pressure and allows a better transfer of energy to the calculus. These features result in a faster,
	more effective treatment as compared to electrohydraulic lithotripters.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.4PT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
	The UDS division&rsquo;s ESWL customers
	are located worldwide and have historically been principally large hospitals, urology clinics and research institutions. To increase
	its penetration of the market segment of smaller hospitals and outpatient clinics, the UDS division developed the Sonolith i-move,
	an electroconductive lithotripter designed for smaller clinics. It is more compact than the Sonolith i-sys, which is more fully
	integrated and dedicated to larger hospitals and can be used as a urological workstation to perform endourological procedures.
	The Sonolith i-move, launched in 2010, brings a novel approach to the market by offering a wide range of configurations to suit
	various budgets and various local market needs. The Sonolith i-move has also been very successful thanks to its innovative
<I>
	Visio-Track
</I>
	ultrasound stone localization: a unique three dimensional virtual system that uses infrared stereovision technology to guide
	the treatment robotically.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Patents and Intellectual
	Property
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	As of December 31, 2015, the UDS division&rsquo;s
	patent portfolio contained ten patents consisting of one patent in the United States, seven patents in the European Union and Japan
	and two patents in both Israel and the rest of the world. One additional patent covering means to move Xray C-Arms has been delivered
	in Europe in 2015. They belong to five groups of patents covering key technologies relating to ESWL systems and associated software
	capabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Three patents, one in the United States, and
	two in the European Union and in Japan, are also in the examination process. These patents concern a stone localization system
	using ultrasound imaging on Sonolith i-sys and Sonolith i-move lithotripters. The UDS division&rsquo;s patents cover both piezoelectric
	and electroconductive technologies associated to ESWL generator, localization systems and device design. The UDS division&rsquo;s
	ongoing R&amp;D objectives in ESWL are to further increase the clinical efficacy, the cost-effectiveness and the ease of use of
	its products to make them accessible to wider patient and user populations.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 27; VALUE: 1 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	27
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage28"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	As with the development of our HIFU technology,
	we cooperate with INSERM to develop our ESWL technology. This cooperation gave rise to co-owned patents in some cases. We have
	entered into various license agreements with INSERM whereby we commit to pay a fixed amount of royalties to INSERM based on the
	net revenues generated from the sales of ESWL devices using co-owned patents. Under these agreements, we have the exclusive right
	to the commercial use of the co-owned patents, including the right to out-license such commercial rights.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Regulatory Status
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The Sonolith i-move is available for commercial
	distribution in the European Union, South Korea, Malaysia, Peru, Venezuela, Colombia, Costa Rica, Japan, United States, Taiwan,
	Singapore, Saudi Arabia, Mexico and Brazil. The Sonolith i-sys is available in the European Union, South Korea, Canada, United
	States, Peru, Colombia, Argentina, Venezuela, Mexico, Costa Rica, Japan, Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, Saudi Arabia and Taiwan.
	The UDS division continues to provide disposables, replacement parts and services for the current installed base of LT02 machines
	and Sonolith Praktis, even though we discontinued the manufacture of these machines.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Market Potential
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We estimate that roughly 2% to 3% of the
	world population suffers from kidney or ureteric stones during their lifetime and that urinary calculi are responsible for 10%
	of urological hospital admissions worldwide. Although urinary calculi may be eliminated naturally by the body, natural elimination
	is frequently accompanied by considerable pain and very often by serious complications, such as obstruction and infection of the
	urinary tract.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
	Since its introduction in clinical practice
	30 years ago, ESWL has become the standard treatment for urinary calculi. ESWL consists of fragmenting calculi within the body
	using extracorporeal shockwaves without any surgery. We believe that the market for lithotripters includes both buyers looking
	for a sophisticated, higher-priced machine (generally hospitals and larger urology clinics) and buyers looking for simpler and
	less expensive machines (typically smaller clinics). We also believe that after a period of fast growth in the mid-1980s and early
	1990s, the market for lithotripters is now mature and has become primarily a replacement and service and maintenance market in
	most of the world. Several geographical opportunities remain in under-equipped countries or in some countries where the national
	health system strategy is being reviewed for hospitals and clinics equipment.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We believe that companies with a large installed
	base of ESWL lithotripters will be most successful in the replacement market. Consequently, we intend to capitalize on our share
	of the installed base of ESWL lithotripters to gain a significant position in the replacement market for those machines. We expect
	the ESWL business to continue to contribute, at historically consistent levels, to the UDS division&rsquo;s financial results despite
	the mature nature of the market, due to revenues from maintenance contracts and demand for replacement machines. See Item 5, &lsquo;&lsquo;Operating
	and Financial Review and Prospects&rsquo;&rsquo;.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Competition
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The ESWL market is characterized by severe
	price competition among manufacturers, with the result that, in recent years, the average unit price of ESWL lithotripters has
	declined The UDS division expects this trend to continue. See Item 5, &lsquo;&lsquo;Operating and Financial Review and Prospects.&rsquo;&rsquo;
	The UDS division&rsquo;s major competitors in developed countries are Siemens, Storz and Dornier.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Sales and Distribution
	of Products
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The UDS division markets, sells and services
	its products through our direct sales and service platform in France, Italy, Germany, United States, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia
	and, most recently, in the United Arab Emirates through our representative office in Dubai. The UDS division also markets its products
	through agents and third-party distributors in several other countries.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The UDS division&rsquo;s customers are located
	worldwide and have historically been mainly public and private hospitals and urology clinics. We believe that the division&rsquo;s
	customer base provides it with excellent access to the urological community and enables it to introduce new products and conduct
	trials under satisfactory conditions.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	No single customer of the UDS division represents
	a significant portion of the division&rsquo;s installed base. The UDS division&rsquo;s marketing efforts include the organization
	of training programs for urologists worldwide.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 28; VALUE: 1 -->

<A NAME="eolPage29"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;

<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	UDS Division Services and Distribution
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The UDS division is also pursuing various
	distribution options that use its strong network of worldwide subsidiaries and agents. The UDS division distributes urodynamics
	products on behalf of MMS (Medical Measurement Systems) and Andromeda in Japan, and laser urology solutions from Lumenis in France
	and from Quanta System in Asia. We believe that the UDS division can successfully market its worldwide distribution platform to
	a wide range of medical equipment development companies, thus allowing for quick, easy and economically sound entry for these companies
	into markets covering most of the world.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
	Manufacturing
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Our current manufacturing operations consist
	of manufacturing medical products in our FDA-approved facility, which is certified under international standards ISO 9001 and ISO
	13485. We believe that this facility can extend its outsourced services to provide device and disposable development and manufacturing
	services to a wide range of medical equipment development companies. Each division manufactures its own products through EDAP TMS
	France.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We manufacture the critical components for
	our devices and accessories, unless a subcontractor can manufacture the component more cost-effectively, perform final assembly
	and quality control processes and maintain our own set of production standards. We purchase the majority of the raw materials used
	in our products from a number of suppliers, but for several components of our products, rely on a single source. Furthermore, we
	conduct regular quality audits of suppliers&rsquo; manufacturing facilities. Our principal suppliers are located in France, Germany,
	Denmark, South Korea and the United States. Management believes that the relationships with our suppliers are good.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
	Quality and Design Control
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The manufacturing operations of EDAP TMS France
	must comply with the GMP regulations enacted by the FDA, which establish requirements for assuring quality by controlling components,
	processes and document traceability and retention, among other things. EDAP TMS France&rsquo;s facilities are also subject to scheduled
	inspections by the FDA. The FDA last visited our manufacturing site in June 2014 with no findings nor issuance of Form 483 observations.
	EDAP TMS France has obtained the ISO 9001 (V:2008) and ISO 13485 (V:2003) certifications, which indicate compliance by EDAP TMS
	France&rsquo;s manufacturing facilities with international standards for quality assurance, design and manufacturing process control.
	EDAP TMS France also complies with the applicable requirements that will allow it to affix the CE Marking to certain of its products.
	Our manufacturing site also complies with Taiwanese, Japanese and Canadian regulations, as well as with the U.S. Quality System
	Regulation. See &lsquo;&lsquo;Information on the Company&mdash;Government Regulation&mdash;Healthcare Regulation in the United
	States&rsquo;&rsquo; and &lsquo;&lsquo;&mdash;Government Regulation&mdash;Healthcare Regulation in the European Union.&rsquo;&rsquo;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
	Property and Equipment
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We have one principal facility, which is
	located in Vaulx-en-Velin, on the outskirts of Lyon, France. The premises comprise 4,150 square meters and are leased to us under
	a renewable ten-year commercial lease agreement signed on July 1, 2015. We use this facility to manufacture our device portofolio.
	We believe the terms of the lease reflect commercial practice and market rates. The manufacturing facility, and principal offices,
	which we utilize to manufacture and/or assemble all of our products, have ISO 9001 and ISO 13485 certifications. We are not aware
	of any environmental issues that could affect utilization of the facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	In addition, we lease office and/or warehouse
	facilities in Kuala Lumpur (Malaysia), Rome (Italy), Flensburg (Germany), Austin (U.S.), Moscow (Russia), Seoul (South Korea),
	Fukuoka, Osaka, Sapporo and Tokyo (Japan), Dubai (United Arab Emirates).
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	&nbsp;

<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Italy
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">

	100%
</FONT>

<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
	Government Regulation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Government regulation in our major markets,
	in particular the United States, the European Union and Japan, is a significant factor in the development and marketing of our
	products and in our ongoing research and development activities. See Item 3, &ldquo;Risk Factors &ndash;Risks Related to Government
	Regulations.&rdquo;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	Regulation in the United States
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	We and our products
	are regulated in the United States by the FDA under a number of statutes including the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (&lsquo;&lsquo;FDC
	Act&rsquo;&rsquo;). Pursuant to the FDC Act, the FDA regulates the preclinical and clinical testing, manufacturing, labeling, distribution,
	sale, marketing, advertising and promotion of medical devices in the United States. Medical devices are classified in the United
	States into one of three classes - Class I, II or III - on the basis of the controls reasonably necessary to ensure their safety
	and effectiveness. Class I devices are those whose safety and effectiveness can be ensured through general controls, such as establishment
	and registration, medical device listing, FDA-mandated CGMP, labeling, and pre-market notification (known as &lsquo;&lsquo;510(k)&rsquo;&rsquo;).
	Most Class I devices are exempt from premarket notification and/or GMP regulations. Class II devices are those whose safety and
	effectiveness can reasonably be ensured through the use of general controls and &lsquo;&lsquo;special controls,&rsquo;&rsquo; such
	as special labeling requirements, mandatory performance standards, and post-market surveillance. The FDA may require the submission
	of clinical data as part of pre-market notifications for Class II devices. The FDA recently introduced the de novo 510(k) process
	for Class II devices for instances where a device is novel and there is therefore no suitable predicate device to support a standard
	510(k) submission. To qualify for the de novo pathway, the new device must also present no more than moderate risk.&nbsp; Class
	III devices are those that must receive PMA by the FDA to ensure their safety and effectiveness. Before a new Class III device
	may be introduced on the market, the manufacturer generally must obtain FDA approval of a PMA. The PMA process is expensive and
	often lengthy, typically requiring several years, and may never result in approval. The manufacturer or the distributor of the
	device must obtain an IDE from the FDA before commencing human clinical trials in the United States in support of the PMA.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Our lithotripsy range of products has been reclassified by the FDA as a Class II device. As far as
	our Ablatherm
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	or Focal One HIFU
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<B>
</B>
	devices are
	concerned, they also have been reclassified as Class II devices. Ablatherm has been cleared by FDA in November 2015, via a 510(k)
	application, based on a prostate tissue ablation claim, following the approval of another HIFU device via a de novo 510(k) process.
	Advertising and promotional activities in the United States are subject to regulation by the FDA and, in certain instances, by
	the U.S. Federal Trade Commission. The FDC Act also regulates our quality control and manufacturing procedures by requiring us
	to demonstrate and maintain compliance with current GMP regulations. Our manufacturing facilities are in compliance with GMP regulations.
	No major deficiencies have been observed during inspections carried out by FDA auditors (or its representative, the GMED, in France)
	in the past few years. In June 2014, the FDA conducted an inspection of our manufacturing processes and facility with no findings
	nor issuance of Form 483 observations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	Regulation in the European Union
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	In the European Union, we have received
	the ISO 9001 (V:2008) and ISO 13485 (V:2003) certifications, showing that we comply with standards for quality assurance and manufacturing
	and design process control. In the European Union, our products are also subject to legislation implementing the European Union
	Council Directive 93/42/EEC concerning medical devices (the &lsquo;&lsquo;Medical Device Directive&rsquo;&rsquo;). The Medical
	Device Directive provides that medical devices that meet certain safety standards must bear a certification of conformity, the
	European Community approval &lsquo;&lsquo;CE Marking.&rsquo;&rsquo; Except in limited circumstances,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	member
	states of the European Union
</FONT>
<B>
</B>
	may not prohibit or restrict the sale, free movement or use for its intended purpose
	of a medical device bearing the CE Marking. Medical devices marketed throughout the European Union must comply with the requirement
	of the Medical Device Directive to bear a CE Marking (subject to certain exceptions). All of our products bear the CE Marking.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 30; VALUE: 1 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	30
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage31"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Pursuant to the Medical Device Directive,
	medical devices are classified into four classes, Class I, Class IIa, Class IIb and Class III, on the basis of their invasiveness
	and the duration of their use. The classification serves as a basis for determining the conformity assessment procedures that apply
	to medical devices to be eligible to receive a CE Marking. The conformity assessment procedures for Class I devices can be carried
	out, as a general rule, under the sole responsibility of the manufacturer, while for devices of other classes, the involvement
	of an authorized supervisory body is required. The extent of the involvement of such body in the development and manufacturing
	of a device varies according to the class under which it falls, with Class III devices being subject to the greatest degree of
	supervision. All of the devices currently marketed by us are Class IIb devices.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	Regulation in Japan
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The import and sales of medical devices
	in Japan is regulated by the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (&lsquo;the &ldquo;MHLW&rsquo;&rsquo;) under the license
	&ldquo;Marketing Authorization Holder.&rdquo; Our Japanese subsidiary has obtained a general license as well as specific approvals
	to import our products that have been approved in Japan. The MHLW also administers various national health insurance programs to
	which each Japanese citizen is required to subscribe. These programs cover, among other things, the cost of medical devices used
	in operations. The MHLW establishes a price list of reimbursable prices applicable to certain medical devices under the national
	health insurance programs and until a new device is included in this list its costs are not covered by the programs. The LT02,
	the Sonolith Praktis, the Sonolith Vision, the Sonolith i-sys and the Sonolith i-move are all included on the MHLW&rsquo;s list
	for reimbursement.
</P>
</EFX_COMPANY_INFORMATION>

<EFX_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW>
<A NAME="FIS_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<A NAME="F20F_040416_HTM_A_007">
</A>
<B>
	Item 5. Operating and Financial Review and Prospects
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The following discussion of our results
	of operations and liquidity and capital resources for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 is based on, and
	should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and the notes thereto included in Item 18 of this annual
	report. The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP and refer to the new topic-based
	FASB Accounting Standards Codification (&lsquo;ASC&rsquo;).
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 3PT 0 0">
	The following discussion contains certain
	forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from those contained in such
	forward-looking statements. See &lsquo;&lsquo;Cautionary Statement on Forward-Looking Information&rsquo;&rsquo; at the beginning
	of this annual report.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
	Critical Accounting Policies
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The discussion and analysis of our financial
	condition and results of operations are based upon the consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance
	with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. The preparation of these financial statements requires us to
	make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosure
	of contingent assets and liabilities. On an on-going basis, we evaluate our estimates, including those related to revenue recognition,
	accounts receivable, bad debts, inventories, warranty obligations, litigation and deferred tax assets. We base our estimates on
	historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances. These estimates
	and assumptions form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent
	from other sources. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We believe our more significant judgments
	and estimates used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements are made in connection with the following critical
	accounting policies.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	Revenue Recognition
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Sales of goods:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	For medical device sales with no significant
	remaining vendor obligation, payments contingent upon customer financing or, acceptance criteria that can be subjectively interpreted
	by the customer or tied to the use of the device, revenue is recognized when evidence of an arrangement exists, title to the device
	passes (depending on terms, either upon shipment or delivery), and the customer has the intent and ability to pay in accordance
	with contract payment terms that are fixed or determinable. For sales in which payment is contingent upon customer financing, acceptance
	criteria that can be subjectively interpreted by the customer, or payment depends on use of the device, revenue is recognized when
	the contingency is resolved. We provide training and provide a minimum of one-year warranty upon installation. We accrue the estimated
	warranty costs at the time of sale. Revenues related to disposables are recognized when goods are delivered.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 31; VALUE: 1 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	31
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage32"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Sales of RPP treatments and leases:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Revenues related to the sale of HIFU treatments
	invoiced on a RPP basis are recognized when the treatment procedure has been completed. Revenues from devices leased to customers
	under operating leases are recognized on a straight-line basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Sales of spare parts and services:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Revenues related to spare parts are recognized
	when goods are delivered. Maintenance contracts rarely exceed one year and are recognized on a straight-line basis. Billings or
	cash receipts in advance of services due under maintenance contracts are recorded as deferred revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	Warrants
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	On March 28, 2012, pursuant to a securities
	purchase agreement dated March 22, 2012, as amended, the Company issued new ordinary shares in the form of ADSs to selected institutional
	investors in a registered direct placement (the &ldquo;March 2012 Placement&rdquo;) with warrants attached (the &ldquo;March 2012
	Investor Warrants&rdquo;). The Company also issued warrants to the placement agent, Rodman &amp; Renshaw LLC (the &ldquo;March
	2012 Placement Agent Warrants&rdquo; and together with the March 2012 Investor Warrants, the &ldquo;March 2012 Warrants&rdquo;).
	The Company has accounted for the March 2012 Warrants as a liability and reflected this analysis in the Company&rsquo;s financial
	statements filed for the year 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 28.35PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The Company used the Black-Scholes pricing model
	to value the March 2012 Warrants at inception, with changes in fair value recorded as a financial expense or income.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 28.7PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	On May 28, 2013, pursuant to a securities purchase
	agreement dated May 20, 2013, as amended, the Company issued new ordinary shares in the form of ADSs to selected institutional
	investors in a registered direct placement (the &ldquo;May 2013 Placement&rdquo;) with warrants attached (the &ldquo;May 2013 Investor
	Warrants&rdquo;). The Company also issued warrants to the placement agent, H.C. Wainwright &amp; Co., LLC (the &ldquo;May 2013
	Placement Agent Warrants&rdquo; and together with the May 2013 Investor Warrants, the &ldquo;May 2013 Warrants&rdquo;). As the
	May 2013 Warrants comprised the same structure and provisions as the March 2012 Warrants, including an exercise price determined
	in U.S. dollars while the functional currency of the Company is the euro, the Company determined that the May 2013 Warrants should
	be accounted for as a liability.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 28.7PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The Company used the Black-Scholes pricing model
	to value the May 2013 Warrants at inception, with changes in fair value recorded as a financial expense or income.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	Accounts Receivable
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We generate most of our revenues and corresponding
	accounts receivable from sales of medical equipment, spare parts, maintenance and service to public and private hospitals and physicians
	worldwide. We perform initial credit evaluations of our customers and adjust credit terms based upon customers&rsquo; creditworthiness
	as determined by such things as their payment history, credit ratings and our historical experiences.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We evaluate the collectability of our accounts
	receivable based on the individual circumstances of each customer on a quarterly basis. In circumstances where we are aware of
	a specific customer&rsquo;s inability to meet its financial obligations to us (e.g., bankruptcy filings, substantial downgrading
	of credit scores), we record a specific reserve for bad debts against amounts due to reduce the net recognized receivable to the
	amount we reasonably believe we will collect. If circumstances change (i.e. higher than expected defaults or an unexpected material
	adverse change in a major customer&rsquo;s ability to meet its financial obligations to us), our estimates of the recoverability
	of amounts due to us could be reduced by a material amount.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 32; VALUE: 1 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	32
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage33"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
	Operating Results
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<B>
<I>
	Overview
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Total revenues include sales of our medical
	devices and sales of disposables (&ldquo;sales of goods&rdquo;), sales of RPPs and leases, and sales of spare parts and services,
	all net of commissions, as well as other revenues.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Sales of goods have historically been comprised
	of net sales of medical devices (ESWL lithotripters and HIFU devices) and net sales of disposables (mostly Ablapaks and Focalpaks
	in the HIFU division and electrodes in the UDS division). The sale price of our medical devices is subject to variation based on
	a number of factors, including market competition, warranties and payment terms. Consequently, a particular sale of a medical device
	may, depending on its terms, result in significant fluctuations in the average unit sale price of the product for a given period,
	which may not be indicative of a market trend.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Sales of RPP and leases include the revenues
	from the sale of Ablatherm and Focal One treatment procedures and from the leasing of Ablatherm and Focal One machines. We provide
	Ablatherm and Focal One machines to clinics and hospitals for free for a limited period, rather than selling the devices. These
	hospitals and clinics perform treatments using the devices and pay us on the basis of the number of individual treatments provided.
	With this business model, the hospital or clinic does not make an initial investment until the increase in patient demand justifies
	the purchase of a HIFU machine. As a consequence, we are able to make Ablatherm treatments available to a larger number of hospitals
	and clinics, which we believe should serve to create more long-term interest in the product. Compared to the sale of devices, this
	business model initially generates a smaller, although more predictable stream of revenue and, if successful, should lead to more
	purchases of Ablatherm and Focal One machines by hospitals and clinics in the long term.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Sales of spare parts and services include
	revenues arising from maintenance services furnished by us for the installed base of ESWL lithotripters and HIFU devices.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We derive a significant portion of both net
	sales of medical devices and consumables and net sales of spare parts and services from our operations in Asia, through our wholly
<FONT STYLE="TEXT-UNDERLINE-STYLE: DOUBLE; COLOR: BLUE">
<U>
	-
</U>
</FONT>
	owned
	subsidiaries or representative offices in Japan (Edap Technomed Co. Ltd), Malaysia (Edap Technomed Sdh Bhd) and South Korea (Edap
	Technomed Korea). Net sales derived from our operations in Asia represented approximately 34% of our total consolidated net sales
	in 2015. Net sales of goods in Asia represented approximately 39% of such sales in 2015 and consisted primarily of sales of ESWL
	lithotripters and consumables. Net sales of spare parts, supplies and services in Asia represented approximately 40% of such sales
	in 2015 and related primarily to ESWL lithotripters, reflecting the fact that approximately 49% of the installed base of our ESWL
	lithotripters
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	that we actively maintain or otherwise serve
</FONT>
	is located in Asia.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We sell our products in many parts of the
	world and, as a result, our business is affected by fluctuations in currency exchange rates. We are exposed to foreign currency
	exchange rate risk because the mix of currencies in which our costs are denominated is different from the mix of currencies in
	which we earn revenues. In 2015, approximately 83% of our costs of sales and research and development, selling, marketing and general
	and administrative expenses were denominated in euro, while approximately 35% of our sales were denominated in currencies other
	than euro (primarily the U.S. Dollar and Japanese yen). Our operating profitability could be materially affected by large fluctuations
	in the rate of exchange between the euro and such other currencies. To minimize our exposure to exchange rate risks, we sometimes
	use certain financial instruments for hedging purposes. See Item 3, &lsquo;&lsquo;Key Information&mdash;Risk Factors&mdash;We sell
	our products in many parts of the world and, as a result, our business is affected by fluctuations in currency exchange rates&rsquo;&rsquo;
	and Item 11, &lsquo;&lsquo;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk&rsquo;&rsquo; for a description of the impact
	of foreign currency fluctuations on our business and results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Reserves for slow-moving and obsolete inventory
	are determined based upon quarterly reviews of all inventory items. Items which are not expected to be sold or used in production,
	based on management&rsquo;s analysis, are written down to their net realizable value, which is their fair market value or zero
	in the case of spare parts or disposable parts for devices that are no longer in commercial production.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Consolidated research and development expenses
	include all costs related to the development of new technologies and products and the enhancement of existing products, including
	the costs of organizing clinical trials and of obtaining patents and regulatory approvals. We do not capitalize any of our research
	and development expenses, except for the expenses relating to the production of machines to be used in clinical trials and that
	have alternative future uses as equipment or components for future research projects.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Consolidated research and development expenses,
	as described above, amounted to &euro;2.7 million, &euro;2.9 million and &euro;2.6 million in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively,
	representing approximately 8.4%, 10.9% and 10.8% of total revenues in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. Consolidated research
	and development expenses included research and development government grants and tax credits of &euro;0.6 million, &euro;0.8 million
	and &euro;1.1 million in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. Research and development costs in 2014 and 2013 included clinical expenses
	for the Phase II/III PMA trials in the United States to expand our leadership in HIFU for prostate cancer. Beginning in 2016, management
	expects the budget for research and development expenses in Europe to level off at approximately 10% of total revenues, which we
	expect will allow us to maintain our strategy to launch new clinical studies (thus strengthening our clinical credibility), to
	continue to focus our efforts on obtaining regulatory approvals and reimbursement in key countries, to continue to develop our
	HIFU and ESWL product range and to fund projects to expand the use of HIFU beyond the treatment of prostate cancer.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 33; VALUE: 1 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	33
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Consolidated selling and marketing expenses
	amounted to &euro;7.4 million in 2015, &euro;6.7 million in 2014 and &euro;6.3 million in 2013 Selling and marketing expenses included
	allowances for doubtful accounts of &euro;0.02 million in 2015, &euro;0.4 million in 2014 and &euro;0.2 million in 2013. The &euro;0.7
	million or 11% increase in selling and marketing expenses from 2014 to 2015 was primarily a result of the increase in sales activity.
	Management expects marketing and sales efforts to stay at significant levels in the future to consolidate the Ablatherm and Focal
	One HIFU technology&rsquo;s status as a standard of care for prostate pathologies in Europe, and to sustain the Company&rsquo;s
	worldwide market position in lithotripsy, including in the United States where the Company&rsquo;s full range of lithotripsy products
	is now approved. Beginning in 2016, management expects selling and marketing expenses to increase significantly in view of the
	Company&rsquo;s expansion in the U.S. following Ablatherm FDA clearance.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	In 2015, 2014 and 2013
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	,
</FONT>
	our ESWL sales activity benefited from continued product innovation and the success of our Sonolith i-sys device launched in 2007
	and our Sonolith i-move device launched in 2010, together with
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	a
</FONT>
	sustained commercial
	effort which allowed us to capture market share
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	in
</FONT>
	both
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	the
</FONT>
	European, Asian and U.S. markets. We believe that the market for ESWL lithotripters is now mature and has become primarily
	a replacement and maintenance market, with intense competition. As a result, we expect total market volumes to remain stable at
	current levels in the foreseeable future.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We believe that our results of operations
	in the near future will be affected by our ability to grow our sales volumes both in the prostate cancer and the lithotripsy markets,
	along with our ability to control expenses in connection with the development, marketing and commercial launch of HIFU applications,
	particularly in the United States, and the continuation of the regulatory process for Focal One in the United States. See &lsquo;&lsquo;&mdash;Liquidity
	and Capital Resources.&rsquo;&rsquo;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
	Fiscal Year Ended December 31, 2015 Compared
	to Fiscal Year Ended December 31, 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We report our segment information on a &ldquo;net
	contribution&rdquo; basis, so that each segment&rsquo;s results comprise the elimination of our intra-group revenues and expenses
	and thus reflect the true contribution to consolidated results of the segment. See Note 26 to our consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<B>
	Total revenues
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Our total revenues increased 20.4% from
	&euro;26.8 million in 2014 to &euro;32.3 million in 2015, principally due to the increase in UDS machine sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	HIFU division
</I>
	. The HIFU division&rsquo;s
	total revenues
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	decreased 2.8% to &euro;8.5 million in 2015 as compared to &euro;8.7 million in
	2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 34; VALUE: 1 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	34
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage35"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The HIFU division&rsquo;s net sales of medical
	devices decreased 18.6% to &euro;3.7 million in 2015, with two Ablatherm units and five Focal One units sold
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	,
	as
</FONT>
	compared to
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	&euro;4.5 million, with four Ablatherm and six Focal One units sold in
	2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Net sales of RPP treatments increased 15%
	to &euro;2.1 million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Net sales of consumables and net sales of
	HIFU-related spare parts, supplies, leasing and services increased from &euro;1.9 million in 2014 to &euro;2.7 million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Other HIFU-related revenues were &euro;32
	thousand from &euro;518 thousand in 2014 and were comprised of license-based revenues from Theraclion.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	UDS division
</I>
	. The UDS division&rsquo;s
	total revenues increased 31.6 % from &euro;18.1 million in 2014 to &euro;23.8 million in 2015, mostly due to the increase in machine
	sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The UDS division&rsquo;s net sales of medical
	devices increased 54.4% from &euro;9.4 million in 2014 to &euro;14.5 million in 2015 with 52 devices sold in 2015 compared to 42
	units sold in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Net sales of UDS-related spare parts, supplies,
	RPP, leasing and services increased 7.2% from &euro;8.7million in 2014 to &euro;9.3 million in 2015, as a result of the larger
	installed base of lithotripsy machines.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Cost of sales
</I>
	.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Cost of sales increased 18.5% from &euro;15.6
	million in 2014 to &euro;18.5 million in 2015, and represented 57.3% as a percentage of net sales in 2015, down from 59.4% as a
	percentage of net sales in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
<U>
	Operating expenses
</U>
</I>
	.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Operating expenses increased 2.8%, or &euro;0.4
	million, from &euro;12.9 million in 2014 to &euro;13.3 million in 2015. Operating expenses included R&amp;D grants and tax credits
	of &euro;618 thousand and &euro;797 million in 2015 and 2014, respectively. The increase in operating expenses included an adverse
	exchange rate impact of &euro;0.6 million. The costs associated with the FDA approval decreased 75% to &euro;0.3 million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Marketing and sales expenses increased &euro;0.7
	million, or 10.9%, mostly due to the increase in sales-related bonuses.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Research and development expenses decreased
	8.3% at &euro;2.7 million in 2015 from &euro;2.9 million in 2014, and comprised R&amp;D grants and tax credits of &euro;0.6 million
	and &euro;0.8 million in 2015 and 2014, respectively, and costs of the FDA approval of &euro;0.3 million and &euro;1.2 million
	in 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	General and administrative expenses decreased
	3.8% to &euro;3.2 million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
<U>
	Operating loss
</U>
</I>
<U>
	.
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	As a result of the factors discussed above,
	we recorded a consolidated operating profit of &euro;0.5 million in
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	2015,
</FONT>
	as compared
	to a consolidated operating loss of &euro;1.7million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We realized an operating profit in the HIFU
	division of &euro;0.5 million in 2015, as compared with an operating profit of &euro;1.2 million in 2014, and an operating profit
	in the UDS division of &euro;1.6 million in 2015, as compared to an operating loss of &euro;.0.2 million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Financial (expense) income, net
</I>
	. Net
	financial expense was &euro;2.1 million in 2015, including a &euro;2.4 million expenses for fair value adjustments on the outstanding
	warrants, compared with a
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	net financial income
</FONT>
	of &euro;1.8 million in 2014, including
	a &euro;1.7 million income due to fair value adjustments.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Foreign currency exchange gains (loss),
	net
</I>
	. In 2015, we recorded a net foreign currency exchange income of &euro;0.7 million, mainly due to the variation of the Euro
	against the U.S. Dollar and the Japanese Yen, compared to a loss of &euro;0.4 million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Income taxes
</I>
	. Income tax was an expense
	of &euro;0.8 million in 2015 and &euro;0.1 million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Net
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	income
	/ (
</FONT>
</I>
<I>
	loss)
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	As a result of the above, we realized a consolidated
	net loss of &euro;1.7 million in 2015 compared with a consolidated net loss of &euro;0.5 million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
</P>

	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
	Fiscal Year Ended December 31, 2014 Compared
	to Fiscal Year Ended December 31, 2013
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We report our segment information on a &ldquo;net
	contribution&rdquo; basis, so that each segment&rsquo;s results comprise the elimination of our intra-group revenues and expenses
	and thus reflect the true contribution to consolidated results of the segment. See Note 26 to our consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<B>
	Total revenues
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Our total revenues increased 11.2% from
	&euro;24.1 million in 2013 to &euro;26.8 million in 2014, principally due to the increase in HIFU machine sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	HIFU division
</I>
	. The HIFU division&rsquo;s
	total revenues
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	increased 70.0% to &euro;8.7 million in 2014 as compared to &euro;5.1 million
	in 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The HIFU division&rsquo;s net sales of medical
	devices increased 303.9% to &euro;4.5 million in 2014, with four Ablatherm units and six Focal One units sold
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	,
	as
</FONT>
	compared to
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	&euro;1.1 million and three HIFU units sold in 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Net sales of RPP treatments decreased 20.5%
	to &euro;1.8 million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Net sales of consumables and net sales of
	HIFU-related spare parts, supplies, leasing and services increased from &euro;1.7 million in 2013 to &euro;1.9 million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Other HIFU-related revenues were &euro;518
	thousand from &euro;15 thousand in 2013 and were comprised of license-based revenues from Theraclion.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	UDS division
</I>
	. The UDS division&rsquo;s
	total revenues decreased 4.7% from &euro;19.0 million in 2013 to &euro;18.1 million in 2014, mostly due to the decrease in lithotripsy
	machine sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	The UDS division&rsquo;s net sales of medical
	devices decreased 14.5% from &euro;11.0 million in 2013 to &euro;9.4 million in 2014 with 42 devices sold in 2014 compared to 45
	units sold in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Net sales of UDS-related spare parts, supplies,
	RPP, leasing and services increased 8.6% from &euro;8.0 million in 2013 to &euro;8.7 million in 2014, as a result of the larger
	installed base of lithotripsy machines.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Cost of sales
</I>
	.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Cost of sales increased 5.6% from &euro;14.8
	million in 2013 to &euro;15.6 million in 2014, and represented 59.4% as a percentage of net sales in 2014, down from 61.3% as a
	percentage of net sales in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
<U>
	Operating expenses
</U>
</I>
	.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Operating expenses increased 7.1%, or &euro;0.9
	million, from &euro;12.1 million in 2013 to &euro;12.9 million in 2014. Operating expenses included R&amp;D grants and tax credits
	of &euro;797 thousand and &euro;1.12 million in 2014 and 2013, respectively. The increase in operating expenses included a favorable
	exchange rate impact of &euro;0.2 million. The costs associated with the FDA PMA trial increased 7.5% to &euro;1.2 million in 2014
	and reflected the preparatory work for the FDA Advisory Committee Panel and subsequent file completion work.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Marketing and sales expenses increased &euro;0.4
	million, or 6.4%, mostly due to the increase in sales-related bonuses and the increase in depreciation of receivables.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 36; VALUE: 1 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	36
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage37"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Research and development expenses increased
	13.0% at &euro;2.9 million in 2014 from &euro;2.6 million in 2013, and comprised R&amp;D grants and tax credits of &euro;0.8 million
	and &euro;1.12 million in 2014 and 2013, respectively, and costs of the FDA PMA trials of &euro;1.2 million and 1.1 million in
	2014 and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	General and administrative expenses increased
	4.0% to &euro;3.3 million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
<U>
	Operating loss
</U>
</I>
<U>
	.
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	As a result of the factors discussed above,
	we recorded a consolidated operating loss of &euro;1.8 million in
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	2014,
</FONT>
	as compared to
	a consolidated operating loss of &euro;2.8 million in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We realized an operating profit in the HIFU
	division of &euro;1.2 million in 2014, as compared with an operating loss of &euro;0.7 million in 2013, and an operating loss in
	the UDS division of &euro;0.2 million in 2014, as compared to an operating profit of &euro;0.5 million in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Financial (expense) income, net
</I>
	. Net
	financial income was &euro;1.8 million in 2014, including a &euro;1.7 million income for fair value adjustments on the outstanding
	warrants, compared with a
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	net financial expense
</FONT>
	of &euro;0.9 million in 2013, including
	a &euro;0.6 million expense due to fair value adjustments.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Foreign currency exchange gains (loss),
	net
</I>
	. In 2014, we recorded a net foreign currency exchange loss of &euro;0.4 million, mainly due to the variation of the Euro
	against the U.S. Dollar and the Japanese Yen, compared to a loss of &euro;1.2 million in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Income taxes
</I>
	. Income tax was an expense
	of &euro;0.1 million in 2014 and 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<I>
	Net
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	income
	/ (
</FONT>
</I>
<I>
	loss)
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	As a result of the above, we realized a consolidated
	net loss of &euro;0.5 million in 2014 compared with a consolidated net loss of &euro;5.0 million in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 12PT 0 0">
	Effect of Inflation
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Management believes that the impact of inflation
	was not material to our net sales or loss from operations in the three years ended December 31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Our cash flow has historically been subject
	to significant fluctuations over the course of any given financial year due to cyclical demand for medical devices. Cyclical demand
	has historically resulted in significant annual and quarterly fluctuations in trade and other receivables and inventories, and
	therefore led to significant variations in working capital requirements and operating cash flows that were not necessarily indicative
	of changes in our business. We believe our working capital is sufficient for our present working capital requirements although
	we have in the past experienced negative cash flows and associated risks to liquidity, and may in the future experience the same.
	Our cash flow situation
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	is
</FONT>
	described in more detail below.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	We anticipate that cash flow in future periods
	will be derived mainly from ongoing operations and any capital raising the Company may potentially undertake. As of the date of
	this annual report we do not employ any off-balance sheet financing. Because we anticipate relying principally on cash and cash
	equivalent balances to meet our liquidity requirements, a decrease in the demand for our products, or the inability of our customers
	to meet their financial obligations to us due to operating difficulties or adverse market conditions, would reduce the availability
	of funds to us. Additionally, we may need to raise additional capital to fund our U.S. Ablatherm marketing roll-out or to fund
	current or new development projects. See Item 3, &ldquo;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	Key Information
</FONT>
	&mdash;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
	Risk
	Factors
</FONT>
	&mdash;We may not have sufficient funds to promote and market -our Ablatherm device in the U.S. and for our ongoing
	operations.&rdquo;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL">
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 37; VALUE: 1 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	37
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>

</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	Our cash position as of December 31, 2015,
	2014 and 2013, was &euro;14.6 million (including &euro;1.0 million of short-term treasury investments), &euro;12.1 million (including
	&euro;1.0 million of short-term treasury investments) and &euro;7.7 million (including &euro;1.0 million of short-term treasury
	investments), respectively. We experienced positive cash flows of &euro;2.4 million in 2015, &euro;4.5 million in 2014 and negative
	cash flows of &euro;0.4 million in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	In 2015, our positive net cash flow was due
	to a positive cash flow from operations and to warrant exercises for &euro;1.1 million. In 2014, our positive cash flow was due
	to the June 2014 Placement, while cash flow from operations remained negative. In 2013, our negative cash flow was primarily due
	to the cash utilization from our operating activities and was mitigated by the net &euro;2.5 million cash infusion after the May
	2013 $12 million fund raising and the $8 million repayment in June 2013 of the then outstanding 2012 Non-convertible Debentures.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	In 2015, net cash generated by operating activities
	was &euro;1.4 million compared with net cash used in operating activities of &euro;1.0 million in 2014 and &euro;2.5 million in
	2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN; MARGIN: 6PT 0 0">
	In 2015, net cash used in operating activities
	reflected principally:
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.25IN">
	-
</TD>
<TD>
	a net loss of &euro;1.7 million;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.25IN">
	-
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	elimination of &euro;3.1 million of net loss without effects on cash, including &euro;1.0 million
	of depreciation and amortization and a loss of &euro;2.0 million due to fair value variations of financial instruments;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.25IN">
	-
</TD>
<TD>
	a increase in trade accounts receivables of &euro;1.8 million;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.25IN">
	-
</TD>
<TD>
	a decrease in other receivables of &euro;0.2 million;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.25IN">
	-
</TD>
<TD>
